text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

ADI IGNATIUS: Welcome
to HBR Quarantined.

I'm Adi Ignatius,
co-host of the show,

along with my
colleague, Josh Macht.
What a week this has been.

We created this show
about six weeks ago

to deal with COVID-19
and its fallout

on business and
the world of work.

Now, there's a second issue
that demands our attention.

The killing of an
African-American man,

George Floyd, in Minneapolis
just over a week ago,

was a tipping point
for many Americans.

It was yet another reminder of
the casual and brutal racism

that is still a reality
in the United States.

For the protesters
that have taken

to the streets in dozens of
cities, the message is clear--

no longer, something needs to
change, it needs to change now.

This is not just a problem
with police tactics,

although that's certainly
part of the issue.

It's a problem with
racism, inequality,

and the unwillingness of
individuals and institutions

to truly commit themselves
to doing something about it.

It's tied in with
COVID-19, as well,

which has hit people of color
disproportionately hard.

We're going to focus today in
particular on what businesses

and executives can do to try
to correct the inequality

and injustices that have
lit a fuse in America.

There are plenty of
us who think we're

on the right side
of the history, who

think we have a good heart
and are doing our part

to help achieve some
small bit of progress.

But if we're honest with
ourselves, most of us
know we're coming up short.

This is the kind of
moment that shocks us out

of complacency, that forces
us to ask ourselves, what can

we do to truly
make a difference.

We have a special guest today
to talk about this issue.
She's Laura Morgan Roberts.

She's a professor at the
University of Virginia's Darden
School of Business.

She's the author
of several books,

including Race Work and
Leadership, New Perspectives
on The Black Experience.

So I'm going to bring
her in in a second.

And I also invite
everyone who's watching

to submit their own questions,
as well, in the comment box.

We'll try to get to as many
of your questions as possible.

But Josh, let me
turn it to you first.

What are your own thoughts on
this moving and troubling week?

JOSHUA MACHT: First up,
Adi, thanks so much.

And thanks for
those opening words.

I mean, I think, like
you, I have been feeling
just so much frustration.

And you can't help
but feel that when

you see these protesters and the
cries for justice and equality.

And it's hard to see so
many people in real pain.

It's hard to see innocent people
murdered in front of our eyes.

And then, at the same time, I
think I had these emotions of,

well, you know, what
right do I have to speak?

What right do I even
have to these emotions?

Because I haven't endured
this sort of dehumanization

that so many others have
lived with for so long.

And you just feel
that come through.

And I was feeling
this kind of sense

of, like, you know,
what can I do?
Or what should I say?

And that's when we published
Laura's words on our site.
And I went to them.

And I'll quote them
directly, because it really
did-- it just struck me.

And I'm eager to
talk more about this.

But she says on the site, for
people not directly impacted

by these events, the default
response is often silence.

Many whites avoid talking
about race because they
fear being seen as prejudiced.

So they adopt strategic
colorblindness instead.

But no one has the perfect
words to address atrocities
in our society.

And then she goes on to quote
Martin Luther King's words,

"In the end, we will remember
not the words of our enemies,
but the silence of our friends."

The silence of our friends
kind of really hit me.
And I felt, like, yeah, wait.

This is not the
moment to be silent.
This is a moment to engage.

This is a moment
to really engage
in a difficult conversation.
And yeah, we've come up short.
You're exactly right, Adi.

But if you know,
we really do yearn

for a world, or a culture,
or a society, or a company,

or a neighborhood, or
whatever that really

embraces each
other's differences

in a meaningful
way, then it's time

to engage in a different
kind of conversation.

And then of course,
not just today,

but what are the
actions going forward?

And it's made me think
a lot about that.

And I think this conversation
gives rise to all those issues.

I'm really eager to talk with
our guest about all of this
and more.

And then, of course, from here
forward, where are we going?

How how do we walk in a
positive direction together

to get where we really
should be going?
So let's get to it.
ADI IGNATIUS: Yeah.
Let's bring her in.

So if you just joined us,
this is HBR Quarantined.

Our guest today is
Laura Morgan Roberts,

Professor at University
of Virginia's Darden

School of Business, author,
editor of several books,

including Race Work and
Leadership, New Perspectives
on The Black Experience.

She's also the
co-author of an article

that Josh just mentioned
in Harvard Business Review

this week, called US Businesses
Must Take Meaningful Action
Against Racism.

So again, I invite
everyone watching

to submit their own
questions, as well.

But Laura, I want to
welcome you to the program.

Thank you for
giving us the time.

And I just need to
ask you, how are you

holding up in this
really, really tough week?

LAURA MORGAN ROBERTS: Thank
you so much for having me, Adi
and Joshua.

And especially, thank you
for asking that question.

It's certainly
been a trying week.

But it also has deepened
a sense of personal,

and I think,
community conviction

around finally picking up the
mantle, passing it around,

and each of us doing our
part to create a more
just and equitable society.

And in that, recognizing
that it's not

just about an organizational
policy or a mission statement

alone, but it's really
about transforming

the hearts and the minds of
people within our organizations

and in our communities
who then have

to enact these policies
and practices that
will help us to move forward.

So it's sobering to
see what's happened,

it's sobering to feel
what's happening,

and it's sobering to hear
the voices of so many people

from a wide variety
of backgrounds,

but especially black
professionals, who are just

exasperated in the context
of our conversation today,

reinforcing what
we've been hearing

from the research
for many, many years.
Which is we are so tired.

When are we really
going to make progress?

When are we actually going
to take this work seriously

and have some partnership and
allyship in doing the work?

So I'm really grateful
for this forum

today, that we're able
to have this conversation

and come to the table
together and think about how
we find a way forward.

JOSHUA MACHT: Laurie, you
point to the Vice Provost

at the University of
Michigan, Sellers, who

writes about the exhaustion,
the feelings of exhaustion

that you just point out
that I think are real.

And in your piece,
you talk about how

this conversation
about race has really

moved from questions
about marginalization

in the workplace to
this much bigger debate

around the deep enduring
stain of racism in America.
And how do we handle that?
LAURA MORGAN ROBERTS: Yeah.

So my co-author of that
piece, Ella Washington,

as well as the dozens
of contributors

to our edited volume,
Race Work and Leadership,

all want to communicate
two important dynamics
around racism.

The first that racism is not
just an artifact of our past,

but it also permeates
our present.

So we're actively
participating in

and co-constructing
a system that
reinforces a racial hierarchy.

And that racial hierarchy
is producing experiences

of inclusion and exclusion, of
marginalization or advancement.

So it's a much more
detailed conversation

than are DNI initiatives
often take up around

just bring your whole self to
work, or just be authentic.

It's really about
reevaluating the structures

and the practices
that are in place that

have led to this systematic
dehumanization, Joshua,

to use the word that
you used earlier,
of members of the organization.
So that's the first piece.

Racism is not just past,
but it's also present.

And the third is that
racism is not just

out there in the streets,
but it's also in here.

So Ella and I wanted
to communicate

that there is a ongoing link
and fluidity between what

we see happening in terms
of the racial strife

and concern and injustice
that's happening

in the streets and people's
experiences of race and racism
within the workplace.

It's ironic that
this is happening

in a moment in history
when millions of us

are and have been practicing
physical distancing.

So instead of walking into
our office buildings every day

and metaphorically
checking race at the door,

we're signing on to
Zoom every morning

from our own environments,
from our personal homes,
from our communities.

And I think that's also
signaling to us the fact

that what happens out
there in our communities,

in our neighborhoods, it
affects our experiences
in the workplace every day.

ADI IGNATIUS:
Laura, the last bit

of really grand national
soul searching on this issue

was maybe three years ago,
the white supremacist rally
in Virginia.

You're at the
University of Virginia,

so you had a front
row seat to that.

Did anything enduring, did
anything lasting come out
of that national moment?

Is there anything
to learn from now?
LAURA MORGAN ROBERTS: Yeah.

Well, I paid close
attention to what

was happening in
Charlottesville at that time.

As an alum-- actually, undergrad
class of '96, wahoowa--

I was remembering my own
graduation walk down that lawn

and how meaningful it was to
be able to celebrate earning

a degree from an institution
where one of my ancestors

had served as a cook and
seeing this long journey,

intergenerational journey
between a position

of oppression and an opportunity
to be able to grow and grab
onto my full potential.

So I had that sense
of hope and optimism.

And what we saw in the
white supremacist rallies

on that very same space
was a stark contrast

to that message
and that feeling.

So I actually was not on the
faculty of UVA at the time.

I was on the faculty of
Georgetown McDonough, which

has been engaging in a
parallel process of reflection

about its own history and
legacy around the sale

of enslaved Africans to
fortify the economic standing
of that institution.

So what was significant
in that moment

was that business
leaders did start

to speak up and make
public statements

about racial
tolerance and the fact

that they were responsible
for this social justice

issue in the same ways that
they had been taking up

the mantle around
environmentalism

and homelessness and some other
social justice issues that were
receiving a lot of attention.

But it wasn't the same
widespread response.

And it, in some
ways, petered out.

So it's a bit different now in
terms of the scale and scope.

The question is not have
you responded and made

a public statement, if you're a
business leader or a university

leader, but when is
your statement coming

and how far will you
go with your statement.

JOSHUA MACHT:
That's really true.

The other thing we
saw yesterday was all

the social media activity
around Black Out Tuesday.
Yeah.

So I'm curious, because so many
individuals running companies

showed their solidarity,
posting black images.
What does that do?

Is that political correctness
at play, or what comes of that?

LAURA MORGAN
ROBERTS: It's a step.

I don't want to be dismissive
of individual and institutional

acts of courage
because we're all

at a different stage
in this trajectory.
Right?

So it's a step for many people
to even say the word race, much

less to display a symbol that
publicly supports their belief

or their espoused belief that
black lives do and should

matter and they're committed
to promoting equity and justice
for all racial groups.

So I don't mean to
sort of diminish
that or make light of it.

But I think the question
that people are asking today,

on the day that followed the
blackout, is so now what?
You made the statement.

You've acknowledged the
harm that is taking place.

Have you begun to acknowledge
your own role in creating
or perpetuating these systems?

And are you willing to
invest in the hard work that

is required for us
to truly experience

that ROI from the business
case of diversity?

Because with the business
case for diversity,

there's a promise
that there's going

to be a net gain from
increasing representation

and enhancing inclusion
in organizations.

But that doesn't come without
some measure of conflict

and discomfort, a
redirection of resources

toward promoting
issues and promoting

people that are working on
behalf of equity justice
and inclusion.
So it's about a long haul.
It's not about a day.

But I also don't want
to diminish the fact

that when companies are
making these statements

and individuals are making
these statements-- when Robert

Sellers uses his platform at
the University of Michigan,

my alma mater, as well,
which has a publicly

contested history
around how proactive

they have been in
promoting racial inclusion,
we should be mindful.

We should we should
pay attention to that.

ADI IGNATIUS: Again,
this is HBR Quarantined.

If you're just joining us, our
guest is Laura Morgan Roberts.

If you have questions
for her, we're

talking about racism and
inequality in society

and particularly,
in the workplace.

So if you have questions,
put them in the comment box.

I'm going to actually
get to a question now.

I want to give a
little preamble, which

is to confess that the places
that I've worked in my life,

including my current
employer, we do not
have a very diverse workforce.

We tell ourselves
the usual things,

that our profession tends
to skew overly white.

That we try hard at
hiring a diverse staff,

but that it doesn't
seem to work out.

I know that's not an
adequate explanation.

And the question, though, that
I'm going to take is similar.
It's from Lauren in New York--
oh, I'm sorry.
This is from Jen from Portland.

So what do you recommend
for business professionals

to move beyond dialogue
to actionable reform

in the workplace
on these issues?

LAURA MORGAN ROBERTS: So what do
I recommend for professionals?

It's each professional again
needs to search head, hands,
and heart.

So number one, head-- you
need to commit to a process,

we need to commit to a
process of life long learning

about the ways in which
race has fundamentally

shaped our economy, also the
ways in which racial inclusion

and demonstrations in
service of racial inclusion

have advanced the democracy
of the United States

and the democracy
of our workplaces.

So we want to come to
a greater understanding

so that we can interpret what's
happening within a broader

context, get outside
of the sphere

of our own individual
experience,

and really try to step
back and understand

how all of these factors
are interrelated.

When Courtney McCluney, Aaron
Thomas, and Michelle Kim and I

wrote a piece about
the impact of race

on COVID that came out
in Harvard Business

Review last week, that
was really our goal,

was to raise the
awareness of this broader

system of interdependencies
that were making

certain individuals more
vulnerable to the toxicity

that exists within our
society than others.

And the APA has declared that
racism, like coronavirus,
is also a pandemic.

And there are
certain individuals
who are more vulnerable.

So that's your head,
the acknowledge.
The second is the affirm.
That's your heart.

It's affirming the
right to personhood.

It's being able to sit and
listen not judgmentally

to someone else's truth and
someone else's experience,

even if you hadn't
seen it before,

and not become defensive
when you hear them speaking

about a pattern of experiences
that they have had,

maybe even working with
you and your teammates,
within your own organization.

But I think what
the question here

is, what Jen is really getting
to the hands piece, which
is the action.

So what are the
range of actions?
Oh, my goodness!
Where to start?

I mean, every time I
open up my browser,

I see another list
of 75 things you can
do to promote racial justice.
So I say that with all humility.

And offer it-- I'll
throw out a couple.
But oh, my goodness!

Once we start
asking the question,

I bet we can discover so many
things that we've never done.

But they range from
company investments

toward racial justice
organizations--

it's company divestments
from organizations

that don't actively
promote racial justice.

It's about partnerships
with stakeholders

who hold similar
values in our lives

and about reconsidering
and perhaps,

terminating, some
partnerships with stakeholders

who are indicating
that they don't hold
those same kinds of values.
So that's on a macro level.

And if you have that strategic
decision making power

over your portfolio
your resources,

you can make those
kind of decisions.

But we also know there
are a lot of team leaders

and middle managers who may not
have that same span of control
or responsibility.

And so they're
wondering what they
can do on a day-to-day basis.

And those kinds of actions
range from just starting out

a conversation in the same
way that you did today,
Adi and Joshua.
Like, gosh, a lot is happening.
I want to acknowledge that.

How are you doing
with all of this?
Here's how I'm feeling.
Here's how I'm processing.

Is there anything I can
do to be supportive?

You would be amazed, if you ask
people about their experiences

and what they're
going through and what

they need to see changed
in your local environment,

they will feel safe
enough and secure enough

to share those
suggestions with you--

as long as they're
guaranteed that they

won't be held or penalized for
being disruptive or an agitator
or threatening.

So that's the last piece is
when people do speak out,

your role as an advocate
is to help buffer,
to help protect them.

When we think about what
happened with George Floyd,
what--
among so many other things--

is tragic, is the number of
bystanders who were there,

who actively participated
and/or observed and didn't
intervene in that moment.

When these kinds
of things happen

in the form of a
microaggression,

but you know it could
be career ending

if it's not corrected
or addressed,
here's where you step in.
And you sort of clarify.

And you call people
to consciousness.

Wait, did you just characterize
him as being threatening?

Did you just say he
was intimidating?

Because I thought he
was just giving you
feedback on your work.

Maybe we need to think about
how we're framing this again.

Because I find this feedback
to be to be quite valuable.

And I don't find his enthusiasm
to be intimidating at all.

It's those moments,
very, very subtle.

But those are the
opportunities that

allow us to start to
move change forward.
JOSHUA MACHT: Yeah.

I mean, you're pointing
to a lot there,

Laura, especially around
being a systematic approach
to looking at--

especially for a
lot of leaders who

are looking at big organizations
with a lot of relationships.

I mean, in the article, you
talk a little bit about I

think it was the
University of Minnesota

just cutting ties with the
Minnesota police force.

And that there are
things that you really

need to go through
and be much more--

you know, this, I think,
gets at your point
about investment in time.

That this is going to be
a prevalent issue that you
are going to be investing for.
This is it.

And looking at those
relationships, right?

It's a much bigger thing than
any one seminar conversation
gets at.
LAURA MORGAN ROBERTS: It is.

Just to add on that
really quickly,

because I know we want to
get some more questions,

but many firms have
cut their DEI budgets,

really starting
with the recession

of '07, '08 and haven't sort
of rebounded in the same way,

or with the same
degree of fervor.

In recent years, after two
terms of President Obama's

administration, many
firms also started

to kind of declare victory
around the race issue

and shift to other
dimensions of inclusion that
are a bit more palatable.

And some of the leading firms
that are publishing statements

now have in recent
years dismissed

or eliminated the position
of chief diversity officer
entirely.

So when we don't have
those structures in place,

it's very hard to commit to
doing this long term work.

ADI IGNATIUS: So there
are a few questions

that have come in that
are really around a theme.

And I'm going to
kind of paraphrase.

But there's a question from
Angie from Minneapolis,

St. Paul, from Christy
from Norwich, New York,
and Cheryl from Washington, DC.

And basically,
they're all asking

what do you do if your company
doesn't take a public stand

or doesn't acknowledge
what's going on?

If they're not--
I mean, you talked

about how a lot of
companies are pumping it out

and whether it's like window
dressing or the real deal.

But what if your company isn't
acknowledging what's going on?

What should an employee
do in that situation?

LAURA MORGAN ROBERTS: Well, it
depends on the employee, right?

It depends on that employee's
sphere of influence.

Quite honestly, it also
depends on that employee's risk
profile.

We recognize that it is
risky to lead this work

and to be a leading
voice of this work.

We know from research
by Johnson and Heckman

that was published a few years
ago in Harvard Business Review

that when white men are
diversity champions,
their careers do not take a hit.
Now they don't get a boost.
Nobody actually gets a boost.

You don't do diversity
work for popularity.

But at least their
careers don't take a hit

when they take a lead in
championing this work.

When racial and ethnic
minorities and women

champion diversity
work, you see,

then, a follow up impact, or a
lowering of their performance
evaluations.

So it depends, again, on the
individual's risk profile

and their sphere of influence
within the organization.

I mean, I would advise
different tactics based on that.

If you feel, and I often like
to speak to the person who

feels that they are
on the front line

and they have the smallest
voice and no one's really

listening to what
they have to say,

no one really cares about
what they have to say,

is there one person
that you can talk

to who has a little bit
more power than you?

Can you send over an
example of something

that you thought
was very well worded

and explain why it
was meaningful to you?
Go on LinkedIn--

I can't get through my
news feed without seeing
a million examples.
You can find them, too.

Find one that you think is
a positive example, that's

relevant for your
organization or industry,

and share that
with a few people.

And just explain,
from your perspective,

why you thought that that
was meaningful or useful.

And it gives people
something to work with.

If you come at it from a
place of blame and judgment,

that's you haven't
said anything,

and you know, without
offering any suggestions

or practical guidance for
what you'd like to hear,

then the person on the other
side of the conversation
might shut down.

It's unfortunate that we're
in this space around race.

I'm not justifying
and legitimating it.

But we have enough
evidence from our data

to support that when people
feel that they're being accused

of racism, they go
into a defensive mode,

and it becomes really
difficult to listen and engage
in that space.

JOSHUA MACHT: Some of
what you're talking about,

Laura, gets at, is embedded in
this concept of anti-racist.

And I was wondering if you could
help us with what that means

and how companies
really do develop
that identity around it.
LAURA MORGAN ROBERTS: Right.

So I think what
companies have done,

and we alluded to
this in our piece,

is many companies have
anchored themselves
in the space of neutrality.

And you also mentioned
this earlier.

In this space of neutrality,
as if either I'm racist

or I'm neutral, I'm color
blind, I'm not getting involved,
I'm not speaking on it.

What that's symbolizes,
then, is it's not relevant.

I don't see it as relevant to
my personal, lived experience.

Whatever problems
it's causing are not

big enough or significant
enough for me to feel
that we need to attend to.

And so I can remain in
what feels safer to me

or more comfortable
to me in this zone
of espoused neutrality.

But we know that the
neutrality is really complicit.

That you're then signaling that
this behavior that's taking
place is acceptable for you.

So anti-racist is coming
out positively in ways,

through your words and
through your deeds, that

dismantle systems
of hierarchy that

make it more difficult
for individuals

who are black in America, and
from other racial and minority

groups in America, to advance
within the organization.

Being anti-racist means being
on the lookout for anything that
doesn't pass the sniff test.

When you look at a discrepancy
between the representation,

even within your own
organization in terms

of the front line and
your senior leadership,

for instance, being anti-racist
is having the courage

to acknowledge and accept
that none of us are perfect,

that our institutions
all have work to do.

And so then, we're being
open and transparent

and holding ourselves
accountable towards doing
that work.

JOSHUA MACHT: Sorry,
just very quickly-- but
you said the word courage.

And as you were speaking, I
was thinking it the whole time.

I mean, doesn't so
much of it rest--

you know, as we started,
for so many people

who haven't had that, been
in some of these positions--
on, really, courage?

Because it's just
so much easier.
It's been easier.
People haven't done anything.
So where's the courage?

LAURA MORGAN ROBERTS:
And the courage

is for some people who have
always been in their safety

zone, in their comfort
zone, in their safe space,

the courage is to step
outside of that bubble

and have to walk in the
metaphorical shoes of somebody

who expresses a
divergent viewpoint.

Call leadership on some of
their actions and beliefs.

So I want to circle back
to the prior question

about what could you do
if your company doesn't
make a statement.

Well, I was offering some
tactics or ways in which
a person could speak up.

But let's acknowledge that
any act of dissent or speaking

up in that way and raising
questions involves courage.

And that people who have less
power in the organization

have had to utilize
courage just to navigate

every step of their career
going through spaces

where they're often
treated with doubt.

They're facing the same kind of
microaggressions in the coffee

room that Chris Cooper
experienced from Amy Cooper
in Central Park.

And so they've had to
invoke their courage just

to keep showing up and
pushing forward, staying

optimistic and positive,
and doing the work.

And so the courage
now shifts to those

who haven't had to be as
brave in these spaces,

or put their neck out there
when these topics come up,

to make themselves vulnerable,
to maybe say something
that everybody might not like.

Or might even give
them some feedback

and say, look, I
appreciate that you tried.

But let me give you a little
